entry.title: New CI Pipeline Restart Extension features: supporting new Pipeline package and improved Restart Job
entry.content:
We are excited to announce the release of Cloud Integration Pipeline Extension - Restart via Data Store in version 1.0.1.

This update introduces several powerful new features and improvements:

  • Supports new integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration and allows flexible linkage of Generic Pipeline copies to the Pipeline Stages.
  • Enhanced Restart Job Integration Flow:
    • Generic Job Profile to restart all integration scenarios defined in the Partner Directory through the Pipeline Framework.
    • New configuration options to persist the Job Log.
    • New Integration Flow "Pipeline API - Restart Job Log" to retrieve both the Restart Job run list and detailed log data (if log persistence is enabled).
  • Improved configuration and monitoring: New parameters (such as "NotOlderThanHours" for Restart Job), several bug fixes, enriched monitoring headers, and better exception handling.

With these enhancements, version 1.0.1 delivers more flexibility, transparency, and control when managing restarts in your Cloud Integration pipelines.

Integration Package content

New package consists of six Integration Flows, one central Script Collection and one Value Mapping. 2 new artifacts have been added:

  • Pipeline API ‚Äì Restart Job Log (Optional). This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of stored Job Logs. It is built on top of the standard Message Processing Logs (MPL) API and allows either to retrieve the restart job log or to query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs.
  • Value Mapping to determine Pipeline Stage (Optional). The Data Store Entry Name includes a 2-letter code for the Pipeline Stage, derived from the technical name of Pipeline IFlow where the error occurred. This Value Mapping allows to link custom IFlow copies to their Pipeline Stage.

Support for new Pipeline integration packages

The new Cloud Integration Pipeline packages introduce Integration Flows with updated technical IDs that include the version marker ‚Äúv2‚Äù. To ensure compatibility, these new IFlow IDs have been added to the stage determination logic.

In addition, the latest Pipeline version now propagates the MPL ID of the source Pipeline IFlow to the custom error handling IFlow. This allows the Data Store entry name to be built using the original source MPL ID, rather than the MPL ID of the custom error handling flow (as was the case in version 1 of the Cloud Integration Pipeline package).

Pipeline Stage Determination

Each Data Store entry name includes the mandatory attribute Pipeline Stage, which indicates where the exception occurred. In the new version of the Restart Extension, the pipeline stage is resolved through a two-step process. If neither step succeeds, a default value is assigned: Stage (NA) or "Not Assigned".

  1. Technical ID Prefix Check. The system first evaluates the prefix of the source pipeline Integration Flow‚Äôs technical ID. This was the only approach available in version 1.0.0. For example, if you copy a generic Integration Flow to create a receiver-specific outbound pipeline IFlow, the technical ID must start with the correct stage prefix:
    com.sap.integration.cloud.pipeline.v2.generic.step06.outbound.myCustomIFlow is resolved to stage (OB).
  2. Value Mapping Check. If the stage cannot be determined from the prefix, the new version applies a Value Mapping. This mapping links custom IFlow technical IDs to specific pipeline stages, allowing you to flexibly assign non-standard technical IDs to the correct stage (see screenshot).

Generic (Default) Job Profile

In version 1.0.0, the Restart Job IFlow could restart only specific interfaces defined in the Job Profile. One of the most common feedback points was the need for a generic Restart Job, similar to what is available in SAP PO, that could restart all integration scenarios configured for the Cloud Integration Pipeline.

This capability has now been added. With the Generic Restart Job Profile, all scenarios where the Partner ID is determined using the Alternative Partner approach can be restarted in one go. The configuration effort is minimal: the only requirement is that the Job Profile status is set to "active."

Optionally, you can exclude specific integration scenarios from the Generic Restart Job by providing them in the parameter InterfacePidExclusionList.

New Job Profile Parameters

The Restart Job Profile now supports additional optional parameters that extend flexibility and monitoring:

  • NotOlderThanHours. In version 1.0.0, filtering was only possible with the static interval parameters TimeFrom and TimeTo. In the new version, if TimeFrom is not explicitly set, this parameter can dynamically calculate it as: 
TimeFrom = (Job run start timestamp) ‚Äì (Configured number of hours in NotOlderThanHours)
  • RestartJobLog. By default, the job log is stored only in memory within the message header jobLogHeader (accessible only when Trace is activated). With this parameter, you can define where and how the job log is stored:
    • attach ‚Äì the job log is attached to the MPL of the Restart Job IFlow, using the Restart Job ID as MPL Attachment name.
    • persist ‚Äì the job log is persisted in the database using the Persist Message step.
    • custom ‚Äì the job log is sent via a ProcessDirect extension to a custom-built IFlow. In this case, an additional parameter must be maintained in the Job Profile restartJobLogExitEndpoint with the value of ProcessDirect endpoint.

Pipeline API Operations

A new API Integration Flow Pipeline API ‚Äì Restart Job Log has been introduced in the latest package version. This Integration Flow enables API-based retrieval of Restart Job Logs, provided that the RestartJobLog parameter of the Job Profile is set to either "attach" or "persist".

The following queries are supported:

  • Retrieve the restart job log for a specific Restart Job instance by supplying either the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.
  • Query MPL details of executed Restart Jobs based on selection criteria, in order to obtain the MPL ID of the Restart Job IFlow or the unique Restart Job ID.

For further details, see the updated Configuration Guide included in the package.

entry.title: A Smarter Move from Boomi and MuleSoft to SAP Integration Suite - Assessed, Automated, Validated
entry.content:
We are living in an era of intelligent transformation, a time when the convergence of digital, physical, and biological worlds is reshaping every facet of our existence. Businesses are evolving with almost breathless speed, with enterprises expanding and adopting new applications, systems, and business models. However, this rapid evolution brings forth a surge in complexity, compelling enterprises to modernise their integration landscape in order to simplify connectivity, improve agility, and reduce operational overhead.

Imagine if your systems spoke the same language, data didn‚Äôt wait in queues, processes moved with instinct, and not instruction, that‚Äôs where SAP Integration Suite takes the lead, not just as a replacement for legacy platforms but as a strategic enabler of digital transformation and landscape consolidation. It silently conducts the symphony weaving APIs, events, processes, and data into a seamless rhythm. Just flowing‚Ä¶.

Why Enterprises Are Making the Shift with SAP Integration Suite

Many organisations who started their journey with legacy middleware are now facing:

  • Fragmented integration landscapes across multiple middleware technologies
  • Rising costs associated with platform sprawl
  • Limited visibility and control over end-to-end processes
  • Challenges in scaling integrations across hybrid and multi-cloud environments

SAP Integration Suite provides a compelling alternative offering native integration with SAP and non-SAP systems, support for hybrid and cloud-native scenarios, and a suite of capabilities for API management, event-driven integration, and process orchestration all in one platform. Cohesion becomes essential when the architecture spans multiple middleware solutions. Consolidating your middleware landscape under one middleware platform brings tangible benefits to an enterprise as it reduces total cost of ownership(TCO) through fewer platforms to manage, maintain and operate. In SAP centric environment, moving to SAP Integration Suite has its advantages. However, the path to consolidation isn‚Äôt always straightforward, especially if the customer‚Äôs landscape has mature middleware platforms like Boomi and MuleSoft.

 Advantages of SAP Integration Suite over Boomi and MuleSoft

  • Smooth Migration from SAP PO/PI
    • SAP Integration Suite: Provides migration automation tool with message mapping automation from SAP PI/PO to SAP IS ensuring smoother transition.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: No direct migration path, customers must redesign integrations from scratch
  • Pre-Package Integration content
    • SAP Integration Suite: Access to SAP API Business Hub with hundreds of pre-built integration flows (iFlows), APIs, and event packages specifically for SAP business processes.
    • MuleSoft/Boomi: Offer generic templates and accelerators but limited in-depth SAP
  • Native SAP Connectivity
    • SAP Integration Suite: Comes with pre-built adapters and deep integration with SAP applications (S/4HANA, ECC, SuccessFactors, Ariba, Concur, IBP, etc.), ensuring faster implementation and reduced customization.
    • MuleSoft & Boomi: Require third-party connectors or additional customization to integrate seamlessly with SAP landscapes.

Simplifying Migration from MuleSoft and Boomi with an End-to-End Migration Accelerator Tool

To support enterprises who are on a journey to migrate from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite, we have developed a purpose-crafted accelerator that streamlines the entire lifecycle of migration from MuleSoft and Boomi to SAP Integration Suite. This tool helps assess, automate, validate, and govern migrations at scale reducing manual effort, improving accuracy, and accelerating time to value.

Here‚Äôs how it works:

Migration Assessment for MuleSoft & Boomi

  • Analyze's source artifacts (zip/process archives)
  • Identifies APIs, Processes/ Flows, connectors, and backend systems
  • Calculates integration complexity
  • Recommends equivalent SAP adapters
  • Produces a detailed PDF migration report to drive stakeholder alignment

Automated i-Flow Generation

  • Reconstructs source logic into SAP Integration Suite i-Flows
  • Uses pre-built templates for common patterns
  • Offers SAP aligned adapter recommendations through template iflows.
  • Reduces development effort by up to 30%

Mapping Logic Migration

      MuleSoft

  • Parses complex MuleSoft DWL scripts
  • Supports in conversion of DWL to Graphical mapping formats
  • Preserves nested structures and transformation logic
  • Enables plug-and-play use in SAP Integration Suite

      Boomi

  • Conversion of JavaScript to Groovy Script mapping using AI.

Validation & Testing Framework

  • Validation of migrated interfaces.
  • Compares payloads across source and target middleware and flags discrepancies.
  • Reduces test effort significantly.
  • Visual representation of the test results.

Quality Monitoring & Governance Dashboards: enhancing the existing Product monitoring capabilities

  • Provides near real-time visibility into migrated integration flows and API's enhancing the product monitoring capability
  • Customized monitoring alerts and reports of the interfaces based on filters set, through email alerts.
  • Tracks SLA compliance, error trends, and integration health at tenant level
  • AI enabled Error Info chatbot which provides potential causes if error and suggestions  to fix.
  • Version Management dashboard across all tenant in the account.
  • Certificate lifecycle management.
  • Alerting mechanism for failed transactions improving the response time of maintenance and support team.

AI Chatbot for auto documentation of Migration project

  • Generates documents (technical specification, cutover plan etc) associated with migration

So are you ready to modernize Your Middleware Landscape with SAP Integration Suite? Whether you are currently on MuleSoft or Boomi, moving to SAP Integration Suite doesn't have to be daunting. With the right approach and the right tools, you can migrate with confidence, reduce risks, and unlock a future-ready integration landscape with end-to-end automation.

Reach out to learn how we can support your middleware transformation from MuleSoft or Boomi to SAP Integration Suite.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here‚Äôs the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: ‚Äúlearn a test framework and run automated scripts,‚Äù we can say: ‚Äúhere are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.‚Äù

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a ‚ÄúBlack Friday‚Äù scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure ‚Äì run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure ‚Äì fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn‚Äôt care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn‚Äôt about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It‚Äôs about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It‚Äôs the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

More information: 

Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
Int4 Suite ‚Äî your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite
Agentic Testing and Simulation with Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph

entry.title: Modernizing RFC/BAPI-based Integrations for a Clean Core with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In most SAP landscapes, SAP Process Orchestration has long been the trusted bridge between the ERP core and the outside world ‚Äî connecting SAP and non-SAP systems through RFC & BAPI calls, IDocs, and Web Services, and so on. As organizations now move toward SAP S/4HANA and SAP Integration Suite, the migration journey isn‚Äôt just about replacing middleware; it‚Äôs about evolving decades of integration logic into cloud-ready, clean-core-compliant patterns.

Among the many interface types found in SAP PI/PO, RFCs/BAPIs stand out as the most functionally embedded. They provide direct access to business objects within the SAP ERP core ‚Äî for instance, to check material availability, retrieve purchase orders, or update financial postings. This tight coupling, while powerful, also poses modernization challenges, for example by not facilitating easy interoperability with external applications, in today‚Äôs composable enterprise era.

Recognizing this, SAP has expanded the Migration Assessment capability in Integration Suite to not only analyze and migrate integration artifacts, but also to recommend modernization opportunities. With the release of Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for BAPIs in Q3 2025, architects can now automatically identify BAPIs used in legacy PI/PO interfaces and discover modern, SAP-managed API equivalents via the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This opens up a structured path for customers to not just migrate their interfaces, but also modernize them for clean core and interoperability.

Note: In Q2 2025, SAP released Clean Core Modernization Recommendations for IDOCs. Now, this feature is extended to BAPIs as well.

This blog dives into what that means in practice ‚Äî exploring three architectural paths for evolving BAPI-based integrations as they move from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite, balancing speed, effort, and alignment with the clean core vision.

A word about ‚ÄúClean Core‚Äù ‚Äì The Guiding Principle for Continuous Transformation

Clean core is not a product ‚Äî it‚Äôs a philosophy. It is a set of guiding principles that help organizations maintain an agile, upgrade-stable, and innovation-ready ERP landscape. By reducing custom code and relying on standardized, lifecycle-managed APIs and extensions, clean core supports continuous transformation without technical debt. The broader paradigm of Clean core, can be approached in 5 different dimensions, with Integration being one of them, as mentioned in the following figure:

Learn more about the Clean Core approach

Three Architectural Paths to Move BAPI-Based Integrations to SAP Integration Suite

When moving your legacy RFC/BAPI-based interfaces from SAP PO to Integration Suite, there are multiple approaches ‚Äî each balancing speed, effort, and modernization depth.

Let‚Äôs look at these three paths:

Approach

Lift and Shift

Clean Core Modernization

Protocol Modernization

What it entails

Continue to use the RFCs/BAPIs as-is and connect them directly from Integration Suite using the RFC adapter.

Replace BAPIs with standard APIs published by SAP, documented in SAP Business Accelerator Hub.

Replace the RFC connectivity by exposing the same RFC/BAPI as a SOAP Web Service.

Benefits / drawbacks

‚áß Fastest transition with minimal rework

‚áß No revalidation of business logic or functional behaviour

‚á© No interoperability. Opportunity to modernise is not leveraged.

‚áß These APIs are SAP-managed, upgrade-stable, and designed for HANA-optimized data access.

‚áß Facilitates interoperability.

‚á© SOA Manager Z-objects are customer-managed.

Key enablers

Migration Tooling (automated flow conversion from PO ICO to Cloud Integration iflow)

‚üπ Migration Assessment ‚Üí Modernization Recommendations

‚üπ Explore APIs on SAP Business Accelerator Hub

 

Kindly refer following tutorial / blog links:

‚üπ  How easy it is to consume a Function Module as a Web Service

‚üπ  Modernize RFC Receiver Connectivity

Best suited for

‚üπ Interim phases where backend refactoring is not yet possible (e.g., ECC system, not yet on S/4HANA)

‚üπ Projects under strict time constraints where migration speed takes priority

Building a future-ready, interoperable, and clean-core-compliant integration landscape

‚üπ Scenarios where no equivalent SAP standard API exists.

‚üπ Transitional architectures that need interoperability before full modernization.

Tips & considerations

The best time to start your PO modernization was yesterday ‚Äî the next best is today. Early planning prevents ‚Äúlift and shift‚Äù compulsions later on.

‚üπ Requires functional remapping between legacy BAPI fields and API structure

‚üπ Regression testing and business validation needed

 

Now, we will showcase how a BAPI based interface in our SAP PO landscape can be moved to Integration Suite, applying 1) Lift and Shift, and 2) Clean Core modernization approaches (We will not be covering the Protocol Modernization approach in this post, as it is already nicely covered in the blog / tutorials written by my colleagues ‚Äì links to which I have shared in the above table).

Example BAPI-based Interface setup in SAP PO:

Consider the example of Material ATP check interface, which uses BAPI_MATERIAL_AVAILABILITY, to fetch the available stock quantity of a given Material, at a given Plant and Storage location. The BAPI is exposed to consuming application SAP CPQ, via a REST API layer, in our SAP PO system. Following are a few screenshots of the interface setup in PO system, specifically also highlighting the request and response fields.

Migration using Lift and Shift approach:

Here, we illustrate how this interface can be moved to Cloud Integration, using Lift and Shift approach, with the aid of Migration Tooling. As we mentioned in the above table, this approach will retain the RFC adapter as it is, in the automatically generated Cloud Integration iflow artifact.

Note: There are additional pre-requisite steps to connect your PO system to BTP sub-account, through the Cloud connector. Kindly refer this help portal page, for more details. This is an essential step, to be able to do Migration Assessment as well as to migrate interfaces from PO to Cloud Integration, using Migration Tooling.

We launch the Migration Tooling guided wizard, by clicking the Migrate button, from within the package.

At the end of the guided wizard, we see that the integration flow is automatically generated, keeping the technical implementation aspects, exactly as it was in PO system (such as connectivity protocols, message mappings, message schema, etc.)

The iflow is broken into multiple integration processes, for better readability. In this case, the request and response mapping steps are modularised into separate integration processes, which are called from the main integration process.

 

The following screenshot shows a closer view of the main integration process ‚Äì with receiver adapter RFC being used to call S/4HANA system, to fetch the Material ATP information.

Migration using Clean Core Modernization approach:

Next, we will walk you through the Clean core modernization approach, to move our BAPI_MATERIAL_AVAILABILITY based interface to Cloud Integration.

As stated in the beginning of this post, we start with analysing the latest generated Migration Assessment report. If you have run the migration assessment of your PO landscape before SAP released the ‚ÄúClean Core Modernization Recommendations for BAPIs‚Äù feature, kindly re-run the assessment. The new version of the report will have additional worksheets, containing these recommendations.

In the Recommendations sheet, you can see the Possible Modernization Item across each pillar ‚Äì such as Protocol, Security, Clean core, Integration Style, etc.

In the API Recommendations sheet, you can see the equivalent S/4HANA API for the underlying BAPIs used in each of the PO interfaces, that uses BAPI based integration.

Next, we proceed to Business Accelerator hub, to explore the API definition of the recommended API:

This OData API can be adopted in our Cloud Integration iflow or be exposed to other applications via API Management layer, to fetch the Material ATP details. We leave the implementation details to you, to model the orchestration layer, as you deem fit, based on your business scenario.

With this approach, we have modernized a BAPI based integration into a modern one ‚Äì i.e. OData API based, thereby reaping the benefits such as upgrade-stable interface, clean core, interoperability, and so on.

Closing Thoughts

Integration modernization is not just a migration exercise ‚Äî it‚Äôs an opportunity to realign enterprise integration with the clean core vision and build a foundation for continuous transformation & business agility, by taking advantage of the modern, cloud-native features and open protocols offered by SAP Integration Suite.
Every interface we modernize is a building block of a cleaner, more interoperable ERP core. With SAP Integration Suite and the new modernization recommendations, the journey from legacy BAPIs to standard APIs has never been clearer ‚Äî or more achievable.

Related Reading: If you‚Äôre working on IDoc-based integrations, check out my earlier post on how to modernize IDoc to APIs and Events, leveraging the Migration Assessment modernization recommendations for IDOCs.

entry.title: Streamlining Data with SAP CPI Message Mapping : Sorting and Eliminating Incomplete Records
entry.content:
Introduction

In enterprise integration scenarios, managing employee data across systems is a common requirement ‚Äî but raw data is often messy or incomplete.

In this blog, we‚Äôll walk through a real-world solution in SAP Integration Suite (CPI) where we:
‚Ä¢ Filter out invalid employee records using Message Mapping
‚Ä¢ Sort valid employee records by EmployeeID using Groovy Script
‚Ä¢ Deliver a clean and structured employee dataset to the target system

The goal is to streamline incoming employee data so it‚Äôs ready for consumption by downstream applications.

Business Requirement
We needed to:
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Remove employees missing EmployeeID
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Preserve only complete records with all required fields
‚Ä¢ ‚úÖ Sort the remaining employee records in ascending order by EmployeeID

This reflects a common need in systems like SAP SuccessFactors, SAP HCM, or third-party HR tools where employee records must be clean and ordered.

Note: 
The entire filtering and sorting of employee data could be handled using just a Groovy script. However, here I chose to use Message Mapping for filtering and Groovy only for sorting.
This approach helps demonstrate how standard tools in SAP CPI can be combined effectively ‚Äî and it‚Äôs especially helpful for beginners learning both graphical and scripting options.

‚öôÔ∏èTools Used
‚Ä¢ SAP Integration Suite (CPI)
‚Ä¢ Message Mapping ‚Äì to filter out incomplete data
‚Ä¢ Groovy Script ‚Äì to sort valid data
‚Ä¢ No external tools, APIs, or adapters needed

Better Picture

                              Sample input                                                                                    Desired Output
           


Steps to follow

  • Step 1: Filter Incomplete Records Using Message Mapping. In CPI, we first create a Message Mapping between the source and target structures (Employees ‚Üí Employees).
    Goal: remove any <Employee> node where EmployeeID is missing or empty.

    Functions Used:
    ‚Ä¢ removeContext : Flattens or isolates repeated elements from their surrounding hierarchy, treating each entry as a separate context so that they can be processed individually
    ‚Ä¢ Length: return the number of characters in the given string (used here to check if EmployeeID is empty or not).
    ‚Ä¢ GreaterThan: compares two numbers and returns true if the first is greater than the second.
    ‚Ä¢ constant: provides a fixed value to compare against.
    ‚Ä¢ createIf: creates the corresponding target node only if the connected Boolean condition is true.



    EmployeeID(on source side) is mapped to Employee(on target side) to only pass records having non-empty EmployeeID.
    This is known as conditional node creation.
    Below is the mapping expression used to conditionally create nodes having non-empty EmployeeID.



    We map the rest of the fields directly one to one like shown below.




  • Step 2: Sort Valid Records Using Groovy Script

    Important Tip: Why We Use Groovy for Sorting
    üö´Message Mapping in SAP CPI cannot perform sorting operations.
    ‚úÖIt is designed for mapping and filtering data, but not for ordering or rearranging nodes.

    That‚Äôs why sorting must be handled by a Groovy script (or other scripting steps like XSLT) if required.
    If your source system can sort data (e.g., an OData service or database), it‚Äôs best to sort at the source when possible.
    But when that‚Äôs not feasible, a post-mapping script like the one we used is the recommended approach.

    Below is the groovy script used in this.



    iFlow Design
    The iFlow created looks something like this.


    Final Thoughts

    With just two steps we‚Äôve transformed raw employee data into a clean, filtered, and sorted dataset ready for use.

    This approach can be applied to:
    ‚Ä¢ HR integrations
    ‚Ä¢ Payroll systems
    ‚Ä¢ Internal reporting systems
    ‚Ä¢ Master data consolidation flows

entry.title: Handling Large-Scale Data Loads in SAP Cloud Integration using Snowflake Adapter
entry.content:
Integration scenarios require frequent data communication and exchange between different applications and environments. Cloud data platforms such as Snowflake provide efficient data storage and analytics. Snowflake Adapter for SAP Integration Suite is a great tool to solve your integration problems while offering a reliable and scalable capability for data-related integrations.

Snowflake Adapter in SAP CI

Snowflake Adapters can be used to implement various data solutions, a few of them are as follows:

  • Transaction Analysis for retail business : Seamlessly load high-volume transactional data into Snowflake to analyze buying behavior, sales trends, and inventory performance enabling smarter business decisions.
  • Data Archival & Historical Analysis : Adapter can be used Move large datasets into Snowflake for secure storage and long-term trend analysis without impacting operational systems.

  • Supply Chain Data : Integrate logistics, ERP, and vendor data into Snowflake to monitor supply chain efficiency.

With this, in the following sections, we will explore the key functionalities and features of the adapter in detail.

Overview

The Snowflake adapter is designed to be employed as a receiver adapter. In such a scenario, SAP Cloud Integration acts as the initiator of the calls. The adapter uses database authentication and JDBC as the transport protocol.

You can perform various CRUD operations on your Snowflake application and choose from a list of different staging storage options, such as Amazon S3, Google Cloud Storage, and Microsoft Azure.  

Below is the high-level overview of how the adapter interacting with Snowflake Application and SAP Cloud Integration.

 

Key Features

The Snowflake Adapter provides the following key features:

  • Bulk Export and Import: Supports reading files from multiple input formats like CSV, JSON, and Avro. Export data to your desired format using unload operation.
  • Snowflake Operations Support: Snowflake Adapter offers support for standard Snowflake operations (CRUD Operations).
  • Multiple options for Staging Storage: Snowflake Adapter provides various options to load data into staging storage like Amazon S3, Google Cloud Storage, or Microsoft Azure.
  • Secure Authentication: Provides secure authentication with Database Account and
    Key-Pair options.


Snowflake Adapter Integration: Practical Use Case Walkthrough:

Imagine a business scenario where 1 million records from an ERP system need to be loaded into Snowflake. If we take the straightforward route of simply fetching the data from ERP and pushing it into Snowflake, the process could drag on for several minutes. But what if we could speed things up dramatically?

By smartly combining a set of Integration Suite palettes with the Snowflake adapter, I have built a custom batch processing mechanism with which, the same operation can be completed in just a matter of seconds‚Äîdelivering both speed and efficiency.

In this blog, I‚Äôll Walk you through how to handle such high-volume data insertion with the Snowflake adapter, and we‚Äôll also take a look at how the execution unfolds inside Snowflake itself.

Before we begin, let us assume that a table is available in Snowflake with the required schema.

CI iflow Design

Mapping Component:

Once the data is received in SAP Integration Suite; the payload will be mapped to required column headers, which are defined in the target table in Snowflake. We employ an iterating splitter to split the records into groups (defined in the Grouping field) and then insert the records in Snowflake. 

Splitter Component:

Using the Iterating Splitter, you can enable the Streaming checkbox to improve efficiency by splitting a large composite message into smaller chunks for processing. Additionally, you can enable Parallel Processing of split messages to enhance efficiency. You can specify this by providing value for Number of Concurrent Processes.

Note: You can modify the grouping, utilize parallel processing and adjust the number of concurrent processes based on your requirements.

XML Modifier Component:

XML Modifier is used to remove the XML declaration from the XML body to make XML compatible with the snowflake.



Content Modifier Component - Payload for Snowflake Adapter Insert Operation:

Content Modifier is used to store the payload to be inserted in the table. The following instructions are handy while creating the body for the payload. 

  1. Specify the table structure including datatype and columns in the <metadata> tag. 
  2. Use the <row> tag for values to be inserted. Below is the sample XML Payload for the Insert operation:
<root> 
	<metadata> 
		<fieldname datatype = ‚ÄúVARCHAR‚Äù>CREATION_DATETIME</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = ‚ÄúVARCHAR‚Äù>RECORDTYPE</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = ‚ÄúVARCHAR‚Äù>DOC_NO</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = ‚ÄúVARCHAR‚Äù>ITEM</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = ‚ÄúVARCHAR‚Äù>CREATED_ON</fieldname>	 
		<fieldname datatype = ‚ÄúVARCHAR‚Äù>REF_ITEM</fieldname> 
		<fieldname datatype = ‚ÄúVARCHAR‚Äù>CREATED_BY</fieldname> 
	<metadata> 
	<row> 
		<CREATION_DATETIME>23012025</CREATION_DATETIME> 
		<RECORDTYPE>010101</RECORDTYPE> 
		<DOC_NO>2020202</DOC_NO> 
		<ITEM>12345</ITEM> 
		<CREATED_ON>01012025</CREATED_ON> 
		<REF_ITEM>011</REF_ITEM> 
		<CREATED_BY>AUSR</CREATED_BY> 
	</row> 
</root>

Note: metadata/row tags and datatype attributes are case-sensitive and must be in lowercase. 

Insert Using Snowflake Adapter

Switch to the Processing tab to perform the Insert.

Now the iflow designing and configuration is complete, the iflow is ready to accept the data.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Demo:

Data has been triggered from ERP and data has been inserted into snowflake.


Navigate Monitoring, you can observe that the records are inserted in Snowflake.

You can verify the same by logging into the Snowflake application. In the Monitoring section, SQL queries are created for individual records.

Earlier using a direct insertion approach, the data load into Snowflake typically required approximately 10‚Äì12 minutes. By implementing the optimized iflow design outlined above, the same volume of records is processed and inserted into the Snowflake application within 30‚Äì35 seconds, demonstrating a significant improvement in performance and efficiency.

Final Thoughts

In summary, the Snowflake adapter enables smooth, secure, and scalable integration between cloud applications and Snowflake. The successful insertion of records highlights its efficiency and reliability, positioning it as a key enabler for enterprises looking to modernize their data landscape and leverage Snowflake‚Äôs analytics capabilities.

References: https://api.sap.com/package/SnowflakeAdapterforSAPIntegrationSuite/overview

Note: The Snowflake adapter is available as part of your SAP Integration Suite license.

entry.title: DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

Introduction

Are you migrating from SAP PO to Integration Suite and missing the JDBC Sender Adapter for various integration scenarios? If so, I have just the solution for you! In this article I will show you, how to simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter using a smart design approach. My method allows both scheduled and manual triggering (without redeploying your IFlow). I'll guide you step by step through my implementation to enable you to do the same on your use case.

Core Insight

You can simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter by configuring the Request/Reply step and incorporating your needed triggers.

My Step-by-Step Implementation

Entire Integration Process

Part 1: Polling and Decoupling 

  1. Scheduler & Manual Polling

    • I created two entry points for the integration flow:
      • A configurable scheduler for periodic database polls.
      • An HTTP endpoint for manual polling via Postman GET‚Äîperfect for testing or urgent triggers.
  2. Manual and Scheduled Fetch ProcessPolling the Sender DB
  • Used a local subprocess with a Request/Reply step to fetch data from the source database.
  • The fetched data is safely written to a DataStore or a JMS Queue (choose what suits your tenant/scenario) for decoupling and most importantly(at least for me): Retry handling.
SELECT * FROM ${property.JDBC_Schema}.${property.JDBC_Table};

JDBC Poll Process

Part 2: Mapping and Writing to Target DB

Write Data to Target

 

  1. Reading from DataStore/JMS Queue
    • In a second integration process, the data is read from the queue or store.
    • Exchange the sender adapter as needed.
  2. Message Mapping in a Local Subprocess
    • I placed mapping logic inside a local subprocess to isolate errors.
    • If mapping fails, it sets a custom status MappingFailed. 
    • Mapping errors cannot be retried, so the message escalates directly.
      local Mapping Process
  3. Insert into Target DB
    • After a successful mapping, data is inserted into the target database.

Error Handling

  • Errors are sent to a global error handling process, which checks the Nr of retries against the configured max and then yields an end event.
    • Automatic retries is triggered with an Error End.
    • Max retries reached, the message was sent to a Dead Letter Queue (DataStore) and escalates.
      Retry Handling Process
  • Mapping errors escalate instantly. They need to be resolved manually. 

Recommendations for Integration Developers

  • Decouple processes using DataStore or JMS Queue; which makes error handling and retries much easier.
  • Design your flow to be manually triggerable (e.g., via Postman or another IFlow) which comes in handy in an error case or for testing.

Personal Reflection

Honestly, I was surprised at how well this workaround performed, especially in terms of error handling and decoupling. While it‚Äôs not as plug-and-play as a native JDBC Sender Adapter in PO, I created a "template" IFlow based on this concept that I can reuse wherever needed. I have already migrated multiple scenarios using this approach, and it is almost as plug-and-play as in SAP PO. If you are interested in the template or have any questions regarding this topic, feel free to contact me!

SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: CPI-Quicks #1: How to transform an IFlow Into an API Artifact
entry.content:
Here's a quick tip for anyone who wants to keep their Integration Suite "semantically clean": How to transform an IFlow into an API artifact.

The Short Version

When using a HTTP sender adapter, logically you should also use an API artifact, because the adapter exposes an endpoint like an API. But I don't always think about that, when I start out designing a process. In the past, I had to re-implement a whole new API artifact, copying and pasting all flow steps and messing up configurations on the way. Until I found out that you can turn an Integration Flow into a REST or SOAP API artifact by changing just one line in its manifest file. 

How-to (Step-by-Step)

  1. Spot the Difference

    • Under the hood, API Artifacts and Integration Flows are almost the same. The only real difference is the value of SAP-BundleType in the MANIFEST.MF file.
    • That tiny detail is what lets you make the switch.

  1. Download Your Integration Flow

    • Grab your IFlow artifact from SAP Integration Suite.

  2. Unzip and Look Inside

    • Open the zip file and go to /META-INF/MANIFEST.MF.

  3. Change the Manifest

    • Find the line that says:

      SAP-BundleType: IntegrationFlow

    • Change it to either:

      SAP-BundleType: SOAPAPIProvider

      or

      SAP-BundleType: RESTAPIProvider

      depending on what you need.

  4. Zip It Back Up

    • Save your changes, then re-zip the whole artifact folder.
      zip IFlow source

  5. Upload as an API Artifact

    • In SAP Integration Suite, start a new API Artifact, choose ‚ÄúUpload,‚Äù and pick your updated zip file.
    • Give it a name, hit ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù and ‚ÄúDeploy.‚Äù
      Create API Artifact

  6. Done!

    • You‚Äôve just turned your Integration Flow into a REST or SOAP API Artifact‚Äîwithout repeating all your work.

      two IFlows converted into two APIs

Caution!

  • Be Careful: Editing manifest files directly can be risky. Double-check everything before you deploy.
  • Always keep a copy of your IFlow at hand, so you are save when you mess something up.

Thank you for reading and may this trick save you some hours!

SAP Integration Suite API

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration ‚Äì A Deep Dive into the IBM MQ (JMS Subscribe) Adapter
entry.content:
As businesses increasingly operate across both cloud and on-premise systems, they need a reliable way for these environments to communicate seamlessly in real time. The SAP Integration Suite enables this by providing a rich set of adapters that ensure secure, scalable, and effortless connectivity between systems. In this blog, I will discuss one of the recently released IBM MQ Adapter.

IBM MQ Adapter in SAP CI

IBM MQ is a secure and reliable messaging solution that enables applications, systems, services, and files to communicate by exchanging messages through queues. It simplifies and accelerates the integration of applications and the sharing of business data across diverse platforms.

The IBM MQ Adapter is available in both sender and receiver modes to streamline message-based workflows and comes in two variants ‚Äî REST and JMS (Java Message Service).

Key Features

The IBM MQ Adapter (JMS variant) provides the following key features:

  • Sender adapter facilitates automatic message delivery via JMS Subscribe variant and Supports Persistent and Non-persistent message delivery via JMS.
  • Supports Transactional JMS Session for data consistency and Byte and Text JMS messages.
  • Provides multiple actions for failed transaction handling: Keep the Message and Process Again or Move to Another Queue.
  • Receiver adapter allows reliable publishing of messages to Topics and Queues.
  • Supports multiple authentications: Basic, Client Certificate, and None.

Practical Use Case Walkthrough:

Here we will demonstrate how to write employee data (sending it as a message) to a queue on the IBM MQ server using IBM MQ Receiver adapter and read the message from the queue with help of the IBM MQ Sender Adapter.

IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter: Write Employee Data to a Queue

Architecture for IBM MQ Receiver adapter

When the IBM MQ Adapter is used as a receiver adapter, SAP Integration Suite acts as the initiator of the calls.

SAP Integration Suite tenant sends the operation request to IBM MQ (this is a receiver system), IBM MQ Receiver Adapter works on the request and sends the data back using JMS protocol to the SAP Integration Suite tenant.

Prepare Details

In the Content Modifier, you can define employee details, such as names, organization, role, and salary.

EmployeeId: EMP1005
EmployeeName: Shubham
Organization: XX Industries
Role: Senior Analyst
Salary: 75000
Join Date: 2025-10-07

Configure the Connection tab for IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter

The Connection tab includes connection and authentication settings for IBM MQ Adapter.

For more information regarding the authentication, refer to the IBM MQ for SAP Integration Suite.

Connection Tab:

Parameter

Description

Hostname

Specify the hostname to connect to IBM MQ.

Port

Specify the port number to connect to IBM MQ.

Example as 31656

Authentication

Select the type of authentication for connecting to IBM MQ:

  • Basic: Provides authentication using User Credentials.
  • Client Certificate: The server authenticates the client by receiving the client's certificate during the SSL handshake and verifying that the certificate is valid.
  • None: Direct connection can be made without User Credentials.

Credential Name

Specify the User Credential artifact that stores the username-password pair.

Example as IBM_MQ_54

Proxy type

Select the proxy type as Internet

SSL Cipher Suite

The specific set of cryptographic algorithms used to establish a secure, encrypted connection (SSL/TLS) between the adapter and the IBM MQ queue manager.

Example as *TLS12HIGHER

Queue Manager Name

Specify the name of the queue manager to connect for messaging.

Example as MQD

Channel Name

Specify the Channel Name in IBM MQ.

Example as CLOUD.APP.SVRCONN

Application Name

Specify the Application Name for the connection.

Example as MainApplication

Transport/Network Protocol

Select the type of protocol as TCP/IP.

Character Set ID (CCSID) for Non-ASCII Names

Specify the Character Set ID (CCSID) for Non-ASCII Names for the JMS connection.

Example: 819

Execute Write Message Using the IBM MQ JMS Receiver Adapter

Go to the Processing tab, select the Message Destination Type as Queue, and specify the Queue Name where the message will be sent on the IBM MQ server.

Select the Target Client as JMS-Compliant and enable the Transactional JMS Session to ensure data consistency.

Processing Tab:

Parameter

Description

Message Destination Type

Select the Message Destination Type as Queue

Queue Name

(only available when Message Destination Type is set to Queue)

Specify the name of the queue to write.

Example as DemoQueue1

Target Client

Select the target client type as JMS-Compliant: JMS message properties and headers will be accessible.

Transactional JMS Session

Enable the checkbox to ensure data consistency.

Advanced Message Properties

Parameter

Description

Message Type

Select the Message Type as Text.

Correlation ID

Specify the correlation ID, which is a 48-character hexadecimal encoded string, representing 24 bytes as 414d5120514d4144455620202020202067d8bf5923582e02

Note

You can also specify an application-specific value, like My Custom CorelID. This sets the correlation ID of the created message.

Delivery Mode

Select the message delivery mode as Persistent.

ReplyTo Destination

Specify the destination as QMGR2.

Expiry

Specify the message expiration time as 60000 milliseconds

Priority

Specify the priority for the message. The value can range from 0-9.

Time Stamp

Specify the message timestamp as 60000 in milliseconds.

Once the adapter is deployed successfully, we can verify it in the monitoring tab. In response, we will receive the message details in the header.

In the IBM MQ Application, here we can see that employee details have been written in the mentioned Queue (DemoQueue1).

Reading Employee Data from a Queue Using the IBM MQ (JMS Subscribe) Sender Adapter

Once the data is written on the queue, now we will see how we can use the IBM MQ JMS Sender Adapter to read a message from the same queue.

Sender Adapter (JMS Subscribe)

The IBM MQ Sender adapter is designed to function as a sender adapter. In such a scenario where the adapter is used as a sender adapter, IBM MQ (Subscribe) acts as the initiator of the calls.

The adapter subscribes to a specific queue/topic, receiving messages as they are published. A subscription enables automatic receipt of messages when you subscribe to a specific message destination type.

Configure the Connection tab for IBM MQ (JMS Subscribe) Sender Adapter

**All the Connection tab details for IBM MQ Sender are the same as JMS Receiver explained above**

Read a Message using the IBM MQ JMS (Subscribe) Sender Adapter

In the IBM MQ JMS Sender Adapter, you can read a message by selecting the Message Destination Type as Queue and specifying the Queue Name from where the message will be read on the IBM MQ server.

You can also enable Transactional JMS Session for data consistency and select Failed Transactions Handling according to your scenario. Specify the Max Delivery Count and Queue Name if failed transaction handling is selected as Move Message To Another Queue.

Once the adapter is deployed successfully, we can verify it in the monitoring tab. In response, we will receive the message body.

The IBM MQ JMS adapter is a helpful tool in the SAP Integration Suite. It makes it easier to connect IBM MQ systems running in your own data centre with cloud-based systems.

It enables reliable, event-driven messaging and supports robust integration scenarios across hybrid landscapes across both cloud and on-premise setups. As companies grow and update their IT systems, this adapter helps keep everything connected and secure.

Quick Links

For information about IBM MQ adapter configuration, see SAP Help | IBM MQ Adapter. 

For detailed information about the IBM MQ adapter, see IBM MQ Adapter Guide.

Note: The IBM MQ adapter is available as part of your SAP Integration Suite license.

Labels

  • Technology Updates‚Äã
  • IBMMQ JMS

entry.title: IBP Integration Using SAP Cloud Integration: Fetch Product MD from addon extractor and load to IBP
entry.content:
Hello Community,

This blog is about creating a custom Iflow in Integration Suite to fetch Product Master Data from S/4HANA system using IBP add-on extractor /IBP/PRODUCT_ATTR and load into IBP

==============================================================================================

Prerequisites

1.Communication arrangement (SAP_COM_0931) is configured in IBP.

2.S/4HANA system is configured in Cloud connector.

3.Add IBP system and S/4HANA system as Destinations in BTP sub-account as shown in Picture (a).

Picture (a)

=======================================================================================

Creating custom iflow for Product Interface:

STEP1: As Pre-requisites - deploy reusable preconfigured integration packages from Discover section as shown in Picture (b).

          SAP IBP - Reusable Integration Flows

          SAP IBP Add-On - Reusable Integration Flows

Picture (b)

STEP2: Create a new content package from Design Section as shown in Picture (c).

Picture (c)

STEP3: From the newly created package, add Integration Flow in Artifacts section as shown in Picture (d).

Picture (d)

 

STEP4: As part of basic integration setup - add Content Modifier in Picture (e) and Request-Reply in Picture (f). Content Modifier is used to input the extraction parameters required for data fetching and Request-Reply is used for communicating with S/4HANA system, where the integration flow sends a request and waits for a response before continuing. 

Picture (e)

Picture (f)

 

STEP5: Parameters are defined in Content Modifier > Message Body as shown in Picture (g).

Picture (g)

 

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="no"?>
<IBPRead
BatchCommand = "INSERT_UPDATE"
BatchName = "IBP_PRODUCT_MD"
BatchKey = "PRDID"
DataSource = "/IBP/PRODUCT_ATTR"
DestinationforAddon = "S4_DML"
DestinationforSAPIBP = "IBP_Internal_UWE100"
FieldMapping = "PRDID:PRDID,PRDGROUP:PRDGROUP,UOMID:UOMID"
FilterForTheDataSource = "PRDID EQ 'ASMBLY-001-TEST10' "
PlanningArea = "ZDMIBP1"
SourceFieldsfromAddon = "PRDID,PRDGROUP,UOMID"
TargetFieldsInSAPIBP = "PRDID,PRDGROUP,UOMID"
TypeOfData = "MASTERDATA"
MasterDataPrefix = "DM1"
MasterDataType = "PRODUCT"
/>

STEP6: Select Adapter Type as Process Direct to link Request Reply to the Receiver.  Enter the full technical ID of the reusable iflow in the Address field. This will call reusable Iflows - SAP IBP Add-On Read ‚Äì Generic Process Flow to read data from the add-on extractors and to transfer data into SAP IBP as shown in Picture (h).

Picture (h)

STEP7: Save and Deploy the newly created iflow as shown in Picture (i). 

Please note here the trigger mechanism is set to start the iflow/data extraction during deployment.

Picture (i)

STEP8: Product object deployed successfully as shown in Picture (j).

Picture (j)

STEP8: Monitor the iflow activities in Monitor > Integrations and API > Overview > Monitor Message Processing as shown in Picture (k).

Picture (k)

STEP9: Output data can be located in IBP > Data Integration > Data Integration Jobs as shown in Picture (l)

Picture (l)

STEP10: Compare the data in source extractor Picture (m) and target IBP Picture (n)

Picture (m)

Picture (n)

 

===========================================================================================

Summary

After reading this blog, you will be able to integrate IBP Master Data objects using IBP addon extractors as source and load into IBP planning area using Integration suite.  Here we used Product MD object with limited source attributes and mapped it to target IBP Product MD. Filter is used based on single PRDID. 

Similar iflows can be built for any master data objects like Customer, Location, Location Product etc.

===========================================================================================

Like what you‚Äôve read? Please share your thoughts, questions and feedback. Feel free to share on Facebook, Twitter, or LinkedIn using the super-easy share buttons at the bottom! And don‚Äôt forget to follow Cloud Integration & SAP IBP @ SAP Community for more content like this.

Cloud Integration SAP Integration Suite SAP Integrated Business Planning SAP ERP, supply chain integration add-on for SAP Integrated Business Planning

entry.title: Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance
entry.content:
Migration Journey Overview: From Assessment to Tooling

Migrating from SAP Process Orchestration to the SAP Integration Suite represents a significant milestone in your organization‚Äôs cloud transformation journey. This master blog serves as a central hub for comprehensive information and guidance related to the Migration Tool and the broader migration process. It provides links to detailed blogs, documentation, and best practices to help you successfully plan and execute your migration to SAP Integration Suite.

Before beginning any migration activity, it‚Äôs crucial to start with the Migration Assessment - a key capability of the SAP Integration Suite. The assessment analyses your on-premises landscape, including existing integration configurations, mappings, custom adapters, and dependent objects. It provides detailed insights and a comprehensive overview indicating which scenarios can be migrated as-is, which ones require optimization, and which may need to be redesigned or modernized. This step establishes a clear, data-driven foundation for a successful and efficient migration journey.

Once your Migration Assessment is complete, the next big step is moving your integration content to the cloud - and that‚Äôs where the Migration Tool comes into play!

The Migration Tool, built into SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs Cloud Integration capability, helps you bring your existing integration scenarios from SAP Process Orchestration to the cloud with ease. Think of it as your Guided workflow for migration - it identifies what can be moved, converts integration artifacts into their cloud-ready counterparts, and helps you streamline the entire process with minimal manual effort.

Migration Tool ‚Äì Offerings and Supported Components

The Migration Tool comes packed with a set of features to make your move from SAP Process Orchestration to the SAP Integration Suite smoother and faster. Here‚Äôs an overview of the key components it supports and automates.

Connectivity to On-Premise Systems: Choose the appropriate connection setup for securely linking your on-premise landscape with the SAP Integration Suite. For detailed configuration options, see Configuring Connectivity to an SAP Process Orchestration System

Object Types: The tool supports migration of integration artifacts such as Integrated Configurations, which define how messages are processed within the Java-only runtime of SAP Process Orchestration systems.

It also supports Receiver Determination, which is available in SAP Process Integration dual-stack installations (from release 7.5 onwards) where message processing takes place on both ABAP and Java stacks.

 

Patterns: The Migration Tool supports a variety of integration patterns to help you transition your existing scenarios to cloud-ready designs. These patterns provide flexibility for different integration needs - whether it‚Äôs point-to-point communication, content-based routing, or complex orchestration flows.

For the complete list of supported patterns, refer to the Migration Patterns

Migration Approaches: The Migration Tool offers two approaches - Standard Approach and Pipeline Approach to help you move your integration scenarios efficiently to the cloud. For more details, see Pipeline Concept

 

Communication Channels: The Migration Tool helps move your existing communication channels to the cloud, making sure your integration endpoints and related settings are mapped correctly. A few exceptions may apply, so some channels might need minor adjustments after migration. For more details, see Standard Adapter Migration.

Adapter Module Support: The tool automatically migrates PGP encryption and decryption modules to cloud-compatible configurations. Additional adapter modules are provided through the community package and can be leveraged as needed. The following list provides an overview: Adapter Modules

Decoupling and Ordered Message Processing with JMS Queues: The Migration Tool supports JMS queue configurations to enable decoupled communication between senders and receivers. In SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration, internal JMS Adapter help separate asynchronous message processing from the sender, allowing messages to be handled independently and reliably.

To ensure messages are processed in the correct order - EOIO, the Access Type should be set to Exclusive, which ensures that only one consumer/worker processes messages from the queue at a time.

Note: This configuration is not applied automatically by the Migration Tool and must be set manually.

Idempotent at Receiver: The tool also provides idempotent message handling at the receiver side. This means it helps prevent duplicate message processing, ensuring that each message is delivered and processed only once - an essential feature for maintaining data consistency.

Reusing Artifacts for Efficient Migration: The Migration Tool provides options for users to reuse existing standalone artifacts - message mappings and function libraries, to their migrated scenarios. This flexibility allows message mappings and other artifacts to be reused across multiple integration scenarios, reducing redundancy and speeding up the migration process.

Example: Enable Reusable Artifacts

 

Migration Summary: After the migration, a detailed summary report provides an overview of all successfully migrated Integration Flow Configurations and their related objects in the cloud. If any object could not be migrated, this information is clearly highlighted in the summary, helping you identify follow-up actions easily.

The Migration Tool does offer a downloadable Summary Report that captures essential migration details - including the on-premise system details, integration patterns used, chosen migration approach, and other key information related to each migrated object, which you can review later if required.

Note: If you‚Äôd like to select an alternative runtime profile instead of the default Cloud Integration, you can manually set it in the Integration Runtime configuration after the successful migration of the Integration Flow.

Error Logs: When the Migration Tool cannot migrate to certain integration scenarios, it generates a detailed error log summary. This log provides insights into the specific issues encountered, helping you understand what went wrong and take corrective actions.

Hint: The error log is available to download as a .csv file. You can import it in Excel and use a delimiter as Comma (,) to transform the data, to review and analyse the migration errors effectively check columns ‚ÄòStatus‚Äô and ‚ÄòMessage‚Äô.

 

For detailed, step-by-step instructions on using the Migration Tool, refer to the official tutorial: Use the Migration Tooling

 

Known Limitations of the Migration Tool

While the Migration Tool covers a wide range of integration scenarios, there are some known gaps and limitations. For the most up-to-date information, refer to Known Limitations of Migration Tooling 

Disclaimer: The list of gaps and limitations may shorten as SAP expands coverage and implements features on its roadmap

 

Next in the Series

Stay tuned for the upcoming posts where we will dive deeper into specific migration scenarios, tips, and best practices to help you get the most out of SAP Integration Suite.

 

References - SAP Documentation and Blogs:

Migration Guide for SAP Process Orchestration

Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite

Assessment Blog: How to use the Migration Assessment Application to get ready to migrate your SAP Process Orchestration Scenarios?

Migration Tool: Migration tool in Cloud Integration Capability of SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: How to Implement Dynamic Throttling in SAP CPI Using Groovy Script
entry.content:
Introduction:

Managing API rate restrictions or avoiding backend system overloads are common problems in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI). When an API receives too many requests in a short period of time, some may reject them, while others may experience significant slowdowns.

In this post, I will demonstrate how to create a dynamic delay mechanism in CPI using Groovy Script, where the sleep duration varies according to request count(header value).

Problem Statement:

  • Rate-limiting is often necessary for backend or API services.
  • Standard CPI configuration does not offer a built-in dynamic sleep/throttle feature.
  • When the load increases, developers need a lightweight way to decrease request speeds.

Solution Approach:

We can use a Groovy Script in CPI to:

1 .Read a custom header (SAP_ApplicationID in this case).

2. Transform it into an integer request count.

3. Implement adaptive delay logic with different thresholds.

Proceed with processing after the determined sleep duration.

//Groovy script
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
 
def Message processData(Message message) {
 
    def body = message.getBody();
 
    // Read SAP_ApplicationID
    def headerValue = message.getHeader("SAP_ApplicationID", String.class);
    def requestCount = 0;
 
    if (headerValue != null) {
        try {
            requestCount = headerValue.toInteger();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            requestCount = 0; // Default if not a number
        }
    }
 
    // Determine sleep time 
    def sleepTime = 0;
    if (requestCount >= 3500) {
        sleepTime = 1500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 2000) {
        sleepTime = 1000;
    } else if (requestCount >= 1000) {
        sleepTime = 500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 500) {
        sleepTime = 200;
    } else if (requestCount < 500) {
        sleepTime = 100;
    }
 
    // Apply sleep delay
    if (sleepTime > 0) {
        sleep(sleepTime);
    }
 
    message.setBody(body);
    return message;
}

How it works :

Step 1: Get SAP_ApplicationID from headers.

Step 2: Convert it into an integer(requestCount).

Step 3: Decide sleep time dynamically:

  •  ‚â• 3500 - 1500 ms
  •  ‚â• 2000 - 1000 ms 
  •  ‚â• 1000 - 500 ms
  •  ‚â• 500 - 200 ms
  •  < 500 - 100 ms

Step 4: Sleep for calculated time.

Step 5: Pass the original message forward.

Use cases:

1. For high-frequency situations, API rate restriction with shorter delays works perfectly.

2. Backend overload protection with millisecond-level throttling.

3. Testing integrations under various load conditions.

Conclusion:

This Groovy script provides a simple but effective way to dynamically throttle requests in SAP CPI based on header values. By introducing adaptive delays, you can protect backend systems, comply with API rate limits, and simulate controlled load behaviour.

entry.title: Application Adapters vs. HTTP Adapter: Choosing the Smarter Path for Your Integrations in SAP CI
entry.content:
The Real Story Behind Application Adapters vs. HTTP Adapter

In this blog, I‚Äôll try to address one of the most common questions I‚Äôve seen coming from the integration community:
‚ÄúWhy should we use an application-specific adapter when the HTTP adapter can connect to almost any system?‚Äù

It‚Äôs a great question ‚Äî and one that often comes up when teams are designing integrations in SAP Cloud Integration. While both adapters help connect systems and exchange data, their purpose, capability, and long-term impact are very different.

Let‚Äôs dive in to understand how these two compare ‚Äî and why, for most enterprise scenarios, the Application Adapter turns out to be the smarter choice.

Connectivity forms the backbone of every integration.

Whether it‚Äôs two systems within an organization or a network of applications spread across the cloud, everything begins with one simple need ‚Äî to connect and communicate reliably.

In SAP Integration Suite, adapters serve as the bridges that enable this communication. They define how systems interact ‚Äî the protocols, formats, and authentication methods involved.

Among them, the HTTP Adapter often stands out as the most flexible one. It‚Äôs capable of connecting with almost any API (Open AI, Salesforce, Anaplan, Coupa etc), giving developers the freedom to design integrations exactly the way they want.

But that very flexibility can become challenging over time.
As integrations scale, what once felt like full control can turn into complexity ‚Äî with custom authentication handling, token management, pagination logic, and error-handling scripts piling up.

That‚Äôs usually the point where teams begin to realize that not all adapters are created equal.
Because while the HTTP Adapter gives you the freedom to build, the Application Adapter gives you the intelligence to build faster, cleaner, and with far less maintenance.

The HTTP Adapter is built for possibility ‚Äî offering you the building blocks.
The Application Adapter is built for productivity ‚Äî offering you ready-made intelligence, structure, and maintenance ease.

So, let‚Äôs unpack the difference ‚Äî and see why the Application Adapter often wins when building scalable, enterprise-grade integrations.

1. Configuration & Setup ‚Äì From Effort to Efficiency

  • HTTP Adapter: Every API call means you must manually configure authentication, endpoint URLs, headers, and payload structure. If the API changes, your configurations or the iFlow must change too.
  • Application Adapter: Comes pre-configured for that specific platform ‚Äî including authentication type, API endpoints, pagination handling, and response structure.

This drastically reduces setup time ‚Äî from weeks to just a couple of days.

2. Authentication ‚Äì From Custom Coding to Built-In Security

  • HTTP Adapter: You need to manually build authentication logic ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs OAuth 2.0, Basic Auth, API keys, or token refresh. This often involves extra Groovy scripts or header configurations to manage tokens and expiration.
  • Application Adapter: Provides in-built authentication mechanisms aligned with how the application itself authenticates. Whether it‚Äôs Salesforce OAuth, or ServiceNow Basic Auth, the adapter manages token exchange, refresh, and renewal automatically. 

No more custom scripts or manual token management ‚Äî security is built-in and standardized.

3. Error Handling ‚Äì From Raw to Readable

  • HTTP Adapter: Returns raw HTTP responses ‚Äî cryptic 400/500 codes that need custom designing or mappings for error parsing.
  • Application Adapter: Provides structured, actionable errors that are already interpreted and categorized for you.

Less time deciphering API errors, more time focusing on business logic.

4. API Updates & Maintenance ‚Äì From Manual to Managed

  • HTTP Adapter: When an API version changes (and they often do), you must manually update URLs, schemas, and logic ‚Äî across every iFlow that uses it.
  • Application Adapter: SAP automatically manages these updates in the adapter.

No code changes, no re-deployment ‚Äî maintenance burden drops dramatically.

5. Documentation & Testing ‚Äì From Guesswork to Built-In

  • HTTP Adapter: You rely on external API documentation, and every change requires custom test flows to validate connectivity.
  • Application Adapter: Provides built-in documentation, predefined operation descriptions, and connection testing directly within the adapter configuration.

Testing and validation become part of configuration, not an afterthought.

6. SAP Ecosystem Support ‚Äì From Standalone to Seamless

  • HTTP Adapter: While powerful, it‚Äôs a generic connector. Any issue typically requires troubleshooting at API level.
  • Application Adapter: Is natively supported by SAP, meaning if something doesn‚Äôt work, you get direct SAP support, not ‚Äúask the API vendor.‚Äù

Peace of mind and faster issue resolution.

7. Performance, Pagination & Security ‚Äì From Custom Code to Standardization

  • HTTP Adapter: You need custom logic for pagination, token refresh, or retry policies.
  • Application Adapter: Already includes smart handling for authentication, pagination, throttling, and error recovery.

One less thing to code, debug, and maintain.

8. Cost of Ownership ‚Äì From Rework to Reuse

A generic HTTP-based integration might seem faster at first for a simple proof-of-concept. But as your API landscape scales, every new API = more custom code = more effort to maintain.
On the other hand, Application Adapters are built for reuse, auto-updated, and ready for scale.

Over time, the Total Cost of Ownership (TCO) is significantly lower with Application Adapters.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

When to Still Use the HTTP Adapter

Of course, the HTTP Adapter still has its place ‚Äî especially when:

  • You‚Äôre integrating with niche systems without a native adapter.
  • You need to handle non-standard API behaviors.
  • You require advanced custom logic not covered by the application adapter.

But once SAP offers an Application Adapter for your API, using it is a no-brainer ‚Äî it‚Äôs about speed, resilience, and long-term maintainability.

Conclusion

In a world where integrations evolve rapidly, application adapters bring the intelligence back into integration ‚Äî not just by connecting systems, but by simplifying, standardizing, and future-proofing your integration landscape.

So next time you wonder ‚ÄúWhy not just use HTTP?‚Äù ‚Äî remember:
Because in enterprise integration, simplicity isn‚Äôt about doing less ‚Äî it‚Äôs about doing smarter.

 

Hope this helps!

Cheers,

Punith Oswal

entry.title: Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)

JDBC ‚Äì JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY

Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API :
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access.

Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. I‚Äôll cover this with a clear explanation in an upcoming post.

Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).

For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section.

Prerequisites:

  1. SAP DataSphere ‚Äì Subscribed account (‚ö† Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported)
  2. SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported)

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide :

Step

Action / Notes

1. Create a Space

DataSphere ‚Üí Space Management ‚Üí New Space ‚Üí Name it ‚Üí Create.

2. Create Table / Analytical Model

Data Builder ‚Üí In your Space ‚Üí New ‚Üí Table or Analytical Model ‚Üí define fields & data types ‚Üí Save & Publish.
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. *

3. Prepare / Load Data

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration.

4. Note Schema & Object Names

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use.
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name *

5. Decide Where to Create DB User

If HANA Cloud ‚Üí use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB ‚Üí use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin.
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session*

6. Create JDBC DB User

DB admin tool ‚Üí Security/Users ‚Üí New User ‚Üí set username & strong password ‚Üí Save.
*Check Active status of User*

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign.

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
Format for CPI JDBC Material:
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true


SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide :

Create a Package & Artifact

  • In CPI ‚Üí Design ‚Üí Create a new package ‚Üí Add an integration flow artifact.
  • ‚úÖ Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts.

Go to Monitoring ‚Üí JDBC Material

  • In CPI ‚Üí Monitor ‚Üí Integrations and APIs ‚Üí Manage Security ‚Üí JDBC Material

     

  • ‚Üí Add JDBC Data Source. ‚Üí Select HANA cloud

     



  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true).

     

  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere).

     

  • Save and deploy the JDBC material.

Apply JDBC Material in iFlow
